conclusion: Analyze forces on each object before and after changing mass of object C to determine rise of object A.
Initial masses: A = 2m, B = 3m, C = m; system is in equilibrium.
Forces on object C: Gravity = mg, Tension = mg.
Tension in rope equals weight of object C since system is in equilibrium.
Forces on object A: Gravity = 2mg, Tension = mg, Spring force = F_k.
Net force on object A is zero: F_T + F_k = 2mg, so F_k = mg.
Spring force F_k is given by Hooke's law: F_k = kx.
Mass of object C is changed to 5m.
Forces on object A now: Gravity = 2mg, Tension = 5mg, Spring force = F_k'.
Net force on object A is zero: F_T' + F_k' = 2mg, so F_k' = -3mg.
Negative sign indicates spring force is pulling upwards (spring is extended).
Using Hooke's law: F_k' = -kx', so x' = 3mg/k.
Initial spring compression was mg/k, now extended by 3mg/k.
Total change in position of object A: Î”x = x' + x = 4mg/k.
Height that object A rises is 4mg/k.
